Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = xe^{i\\omega t}\\) where \\(x\\) and \\(\\omega\\) are constants. The transformation \(\ T : z \mapsto z^2 \) is applied to this function.

If the transformation \( T \) is applied to \( z(t) \) at time \( t = 0 \), leading to \( T(z(0)) = (xe^{i\\omega \\times 0})^2 = x^2 \), and then \( z(t) \) is allowed to evolve without further intervention, will the values of \( z(t) \) at \( t = T \) be the same as directly evolving \( z(t) = xe^{i\\omega t} \) without applying \( T \) at the initial time?
Explanation: Applying \( T \) modifies the initial condition and thus the trajectory of the system. Direct evolution without applying \( T \) results in \( xe^{i\\omega T} \), whereas evolving \( T(z(0)) = x^2 \) leads to \( x^2e^{i\\omega T} \), showing a squared magnitude and thus a different trajectory.
